posts.cooked: Hi, I am making a design that uses Krakens to change angles with the shooter etc… The coding group is well versed in the Rev ecosystem and refuses to make the switch. How hard would it be use Krakens as ex. shooter pivot in coding? (I can’t switch drop in Neo’s for the Kraken due to limitations of the design) I’m purely a mechanical/design lead with basic knowledge in coding.

It is different, but if they read through docs and play around with it could likely have it working pretty quick. I am a mechanical guy my team has pretty much been all REV since the Neos came out. We bought a few Krakens to test in the off season. In less than about two to three hours of playing around I had our 2022 elevator running faster with better control than we ever had with the Neos during the season. Motion Magic is pretty dang cool.

posts.name: Owen Shaule
posts.cooked:
overclockedfyre:

The coding group is well versed in the Rev ecosystem and refuses to make the switch.

From someone that use’s both REVLib and Phoenix 6 (the library for controlling Krakens), both have relatively the same difficulty to learn if you have a motor on hand, with some differences (requests vs just setting a reference for the controller and some syntax stuff), but I’ve found Phoenix 6 to have greater quality control and more options for controlling mechanisms.

overclockedfyre:

How hard would it be use Krakens as ex. shooter pivot in coding?

Cross The Road Electronics provides examples for controlling position with either a CTRE encoder or the Kraken’s built in encoder. I would also suggest using MotionMagic, which is a much more polished version of REV’s SmartMotion (so you can control acceleration and max speed instead of going full tilt with a standard PID controller).

I wouldn’t start to learn Phoenix 6 at the start of a season but getting 1 or 2 Kraken’s offseason for programmers to learn and a design/build sub team to work with isnt a bad idea.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Basically everything is easier in the CTRE ecosystem right now, except for using external encoders.

Switching should be painless as long as you are comfortable reading API documentation.
